comment._content: Standard Chemical Co. known under a variety of names, including: Standard Chemical, Iron and Lumber of Canada Ltd. which became the Standard Chemical Co. Ltd. of Toronto, by supplementary letters patent in 1918. This and the Parry Sound plant established in 1912 used charcoal to fire the blast furnaces. Charcoal burned hotter than coal, note: the charcoal bins above the smelter in this diagram. About this time coke was introduced as a fuel for blast furnaces, produced from coal, it burned hotter than charcoal, making plants such as this uneconomical. The chemicals of the firm's namesake, were a byproduct from their manufacture of charcoal, at plants such as Longford Mills and South River. The firm's production of Acetate of Lime, Wood Alcohol and Pig Iron were high in demand during wartime, however, as the need for their products declined the plants closed. When did the Deseronto smelter shut down?

comment.author: 23121382@N07
comment._content: I don't know exactly when the smelter was shut down, but the fire insurance plan for March 1922 shows the Standard Iron Company site as 'silent' at that point.
